data.title: What do the Edmonton Oilers come away with from the 2015 NHL Draft?
data.meta_description: The Edmonton Oilers were awfully busy over the weekend, finding themselves at the centre of no fewer than four trades with two of those being significant deals. New…
data.text:
Article content

The Edmonton Oilers were awfully busy over the weekend, finding themselves at the centre of no fewer than four trades with two of those being significant deals. New general manager Peter Chiarelli started to put his stamp on the team, both with the trades and with the picks themselves.

What does the team’s work look like in the big picture? Let’s walk through the club’s decisions.

Article content

Oilers draft C Connor McDavid No. 1 overall. No surprises here. McDavid is now the most important piece of the Oilers’ franchise, the rock that the team will be built on for the next decade. Edmonton is incredibly fortunate to get this player.

Oilers acquire D Griffin Reinhart from the Islanders for the No. 16 and No. 33 picks. Edmonton adds the big ex-Oil King it has coveted for many years. Reinhart should be expected to compete for a third-pairing job in training camp next season. A natural left side defenceman, he also has experience on the right.

Oilers acquire G Cam Talbot and the No. 209 pick from the Rangers for the No. 57, No. 79 and No. 184 picks. The Oilers out-waited Rangers’ GM Glen Sather, and ended up with the goalie they coveted at a pretty reasonable price.

Oilers send No. 86 pick to the Sharks as compensation for head coach Todd McLellan. A little housekeeping costs Edmonton a third-round pick, but takes care of their compensation obligation toward San Jose immediately.

Oilers acquire F Brad Ross, No. 107 pick from Maple Leafs for D Martin Marincin. Polarizing defenceman Martin Marincin gets a fresh start with a new organization; the Oilers add a draft pick.

Article content

Oilers acquire D Eric Gryba from the Senators for F Travis Ewanyk and the No. 107 pick. So long, No. 107; we hardly knew you. With one third-pair defenceman gone, the Oilers immediately replace him with a new one from Ottawa.

Oilers draft D Caleb Jones No. 117 overall. Now, you do eventually plan to have draft picks, at this entry draft, right? After doing everything but draft, Edmonton adds Seth Jones’ little brother in the fourth round.

Oilers draft D Ethan Bear No. 124 overall. Immediately after drafting Jones, the Oilers add an intense shutdown defenceman in the WHL’s Ethan Bear, who only just turned 18 on Saturday.

Oilers draft D John Marino No. 154 overall. The blue line was a theme late, as Edmonton added 6’2″ right-shooting rearguard Marino as their third consecutive defence pick. He’s Harvard-bound.

Oilers draft G Miroslav Svoboda No. 208 overall. Edmonton did suggest that a goalie would be entering the system at the draft, though possibly most expected him to be added al ittle earlier in the day. This pick came via trade from Tampa Bay for a 2016 seventh-round pick the Oilers had previously got from Dallas.

Oilers draft D Ziyat Paigin No. 209 overall. Back to the blue line for the Oilers’ final pick. Paigin is a big KHL defenceman and continues Edmonton’s recent interest in Russia as a draft day fishing hole.
